commentBody: Voting is now open for the final round of the 2024 Puzzle of the Year awards, a/k/a the Griddies. You can find the ballot at https://form.jotform.com/250186385916162. Voting ends at 11:59 PM, Friday, January 31. We plan to announce the winners next Sunday, February 2. Again, puzzles are divided into four categories: Early Week (Monday‚ÄìWednesday), Thursday, Themeless (Friday and Saturday) and Sunday. There are five finalists in each category and you may vote for one puzzle in each category. Thanks again to everyone who nominated a puzzle. And thanks also to Cat Lady Margaret and John Ezra for their assistance in helping me make sure the ballots reflect the Wordplay community‚Äôs preferences.

A rebus puzzle that is not a rebus puzzle!
Will everyone love it or will everyone hate it?
Or will people just be cross about the words?
It's Sunday; anything can happen.

I thought it was cute. Easy but cute.

Hope you still have a day job, Rich, and that's a serious comment, not a knock on your construction.

Well, this was a worthy workout for a weekend evening with nothing happening. It would have been very frustrating if someone was waiting for me to finish to go out to dinner!

I will say that I finished much slower (half again my Sunday average) with this one, and I'm trying to decide how much of this was circumstances, and how much it was the puzzle itself.

The only circumstance that could have been a factor was that I had taken a nap just before puzzle time and apparently slept very deeply, as I woke up kind of groggy. But I still had 15 minutes to wake up before starting, so I think that was only a slight factor.

I think it was mostly the puzzle. This is a trick I've never seen before; of course, we've occasionally had picture rebuses before, but never quite this way. Not knowing how the trick worked made two crossing answers opaque, muddling whole areas until the gimmick is figured out. I also had non-theme slowdowns, especially in the NW, where it was all CLEAR AS MUD.  One thing holding me up was INCAS. I couldn'f figure out how to make BIRDSEYE fit, and after that, figured it had to be another brand.  As a Lexington Avenue resident once said, "Who knew?"

I've said that I now solve with a sense of "when, not if" I'll finish, but this puzzle made me wonder if I would need to take a break, or if it would break me. In the end, it got done, and I was glad I was careful to avoid typos, because not hearing the music would have been devastating!

Having shared my personal experience in the previous post, I'd like to add that I'll bet that today's comments will include many people who rail about the puzzle being too hard (I thought it was hard in a good way) and those who say it wasn't fair and it wasn't a crossword (or that crosswords should be...fill in whatever you want).

I can see how people with less crossword experience might have major gripes with this one.

Gust for GALE probably added 10 minutes to my solving time. I finally caught on to the trick with GIVE OFF/EMIT, but I still struggled to finish the NW corner.

This was the most challenging Sunday puzzle in weeks, not so much because of the clue drawings but because of the "See __ Down" clues.

MOORE‚Äôs law made me wonder if there might be ‚Äúlaws‚Äù describing how things happen in crosswords.

Using the constructor comments, I‚Äôll start:

Proulx‚Äôs law: Any puzzle requiring the use of a monocle will lead to strife.*

Any other laws y‚Äôall care to chime in with?

*(p.s. no strife on today‚Äôs puzzle; it was fun.)
How cool that the circled letters spell 'REBUSES'.

Having read the puzzle's explanation at the top, I rolled my eyes and said to myself, "oh please." Then I did the first theme and I immediately fell in love with this construction. Thank you Rich Proulx for an enjoyable experience.
Can you please present Sunday puzzles that aren't so gimmicky, please?

Put me in the "loved it" column for this Sunday workout. It took me a good while to catch onto the theme. I needed a critical mass of non-theme crosses to get a toehold. All the way down to "give off "/"emit" the aha moment finally hit. After that, it was a delight to sound out the remaining themes. Well done.

That was fun! I totally enjoyed figuring out the theme, pictorially speaking. 

I most like the ones where the spelling of the entry differs from the spelling of the illustration. RODE rather than road, NIT rather than knit, PY rather than pie. So clever. 

Cute clue for ITALIC. 

PROPS, Rich, for spelling REBUSES with the circles. Great construction!
I was not fond of this theme. But that's ok, I don't have to love every puzzle I do.
Love it!
Also, ESCAPE doesn't really work, right? It should technically be ECAPE.
Ardency??      What?

Well that took a while. You can take the usual complaints about proper names as a given, but what messed me up the most was filling in "schwa" for the vowel sound.  Between not thinking of "Gold Medal" as a brand name, and with both that and the themed "See __ down" crossing it, nothing was making sense for quite a while.

But eventually I got there just a couple of minutes over my average time, and had fun along the way.

Didn't like that in some of the themed clues the illustration was spelled correctly (e.g. CAPE, TRAY) while in others it was phonetic (e.g. NIT, PY). Wasn't a fan of the fill either (ARDENCY, really?). Sunday continues to be the worst puzzle of the week.

Kind of fun, with easy to moderate difficulty.

But I didn't much like the theme execution or, especially, the drawings.

An okay Sunday to me.  It would have been better had the theme been omitted.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Each theme answer was a lovely ruse. Perhaps the loveliest was 46D ‚Äì BETRAY (with the picture of the tray in the clue) ‚Äì loveliest because it was a ‚Äúb-ruse‚Äù, which anagrams to ‚Ä¶ 





Et tu, emu.

On the January 18 puzzle when everyone was complaining about the cluing for "Hotel California," I commented that you could still figure it out from the crosses. I went looking for a wildly obscure 15-letter album title from that year to say, "hey, at least it's not this!" I settled on "Joan Armatrading." 

Fast forward to today. My wife and I are running errands and we're listening to Dallas's fantastic NPR music statio, KXT. And what do they play but... "Down To Zero" by Joan Armatrading.

Anyway, I thought the seams were showing a little bit on this puzzle, but there have been much worse lately.

Thank you, Mr. Proulx, for this super engaging puzzle, and Mr. Savage, for the smart doodles. 

I loved the idea of the across clue being non-existent and depending on the down entry. Puzzles within puzzles make me happy to no end.

The rest of the puzzle was challenging, but also perked me up ‚Äì for instance, I could hardly wait to find out who were the pioneers of freeze-drying food. 
It was also only today that I learned about NO BRA DAY. I'm a woman; shame on me for not knowing about that.  Live and learn.

On another note, I just want to add that I was very moved by Caitlin's choice of a picture today. 
Seeing these elderly women with their grey and white manes, being honored for their service in WW II, tugged at my heartstrings and deeply touched me in a good way.

Thank you, Caitlin, and thank you again, Mr. Proulx. 
You've both put a smile on my face.
Really challenging puzzle! - doubled my usual time. But I enjoyed it. Thanks and good to see you back, Will.

I quite liked the gimmick; once I figured out how it worked, it was fun to try tackling some with the down clues (‚Äúhmm, a letter plus ‚Äòcane‚Äô‚Äîoh, ARCANE!), some with the across clues (based purely on crosses), and some from looking at both together.

I did find one area a bit naticky for me, and so that was the last part I labored at before eventually giving up and Googling to get the chime: I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever heard of Ms. ROSSELLINI (though I have apparently seen her in a few movies‚Äîbut not Conclave). I‚Äôm also pretty clueless about sports, so I thought An OUT was plausible baseball-ese. (Now that I think about it, I guess I have heard the word ‚Äúfault‚Äù in association with tennis, but that still wouldn‚Äôt have got me the [TIL] abbreviation of ‚Äúadvantage out.‚Äù) Finally, both Ms. Radner‚Äôs surname and (post-solve) her full name ring a bell faintly, but I wasn‚Äôt alive when she was on SNL, so that ringing wasn‚Äôt any clearer than ‚ÄúI think it must start with a ‚ÄòG‚Äô and end with an ‚ÄòA‚Äô‚Äù‚Äîalready clear from crosses I was sure of.

I was pretty certain the Latin was IDEM (after having conclusively ruled out ‚Äúibid.‚Äù from crosses), but those names and the sports term eventually had me doubting even that. (‚ÄúGiala? Genna? Golda?‚Äù) It turned out that I‚Äôd guessed the Italian actresses‚Äôs name correctly based on phonology, so all I had needed to do was keep that and the footnote phrase as I‚Äôd originally entered them and change An to AD. Oh, well. The rest of the puzzle solved smoothly.

It took me awhile to unpack the theme on this one.  CLEARASMUD as the match for ARCANE seemed like a bit of a stretch.  I struggled to come up with EATAWAY/ERODE partly because I couldn‚Äôt come with RIA  or AIDE for number two (my mind went in a couple of different directions on that one), and that little box where those answers resided offered relatively few crosses.  Eventually the light bulb went on.  The other theme pairs made sense and were relatively easy to suss out.

I had a good -- and long -- time doing this puzzle. 

You might have missed it in the flurry, but the EEO is no more. Donald got rid of it a couple days ago. First enacted as an executive order by Lyndon Johnson in 1965, the EEO mandated that employers could not discriminate based on gender, color, or any other biases,  "without regard to their race, creed, color, or national origin." Congress made it an official act in 1972. It was often identified with "affirmative action," which made it a target for (mainly) white conservative politicians. In his statement about EEO, Donald said that because of it, American companies "have adopted and actively use dangerous, demeaning, and immoral race- and sex-based preferences," and that these DEI practices "can violate the civil-rights laws of this Nation."
Off the subject at hand...what happened to "ink saver" when printing out the puzzle. Love the puzzles, but hate spending a fortune on ink!
Still not a fan of these kind of puzzles. Even so, I was able to solve in my average time.

Was a stuck awhile on the ERODE / EAT AWAY combo, as well -- following the bouncing rebus balls would have come to the rescue.  D'oh well .....

Brilliant companion to Saturday's brain buster.

Enjoyed this one, although it took a minute for the penny to drop!

Seeing EEO in the crossword made me sad. It's heartbreaking to watch the US devolve from my little corner of London. It's enough to make one "stress-eat" (see what I did there). 

It took me eons to figure out how the picture clues fitted in with the rest of the puzzle but once did, I was pretty impressed by the creativity. 

I did find it tough and had to lookup four or five answers. I'm sure trying to solve it at 2am on Sunday morning straight after completing that killer Saturday puzzle was a bad idea but the naticks didn't help either:

- ELENA and ALAINA
- MEGAN with MIRREN (these I knew as I'm a big fan of both)
- ROSSELLINI with GILDA. I knew the former but the latter also crossed with IDEM (which I'd forgotten as I haven't read a research paper in yonks) and ADOUT (which was also a bust as I don't watch tennis). 

TIL:
- OSH Kosh B'Gosh is an actual store. I've heard it said many time but I thought it was just a random cobbling of non-words that sounded funny.
- ARDENCY is a word. I kept trying to stretch ARDOR out. Even the British spelling didn't fit! ü§¶üèæ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
- AGESPECS are not a thing ü§ì
- TIL stands for things I learned üòÜ

Special mention to 18A. Lifted one's spirits for MADEATOAST was inspired üëèüèæ 

I hadn't heard of the Weird Al parody of Wiz Khalifa's Black and Yellow (White & NERDY) but I do love the Funny or Die version called Black and Jewish which hilariously laments the plight of the forgotten subsection of the Jewish population... the Black Jewish. Check it out.
This was not nearly as easy as the usual Sunday puzzles, and I'm not even referring to the gimmick clues. The answers to the regular clues just didn't seem as clear-cut as usual.

It seemed to me that STEeLS UPON was good enough and that THREE D would have helped Theseus in giving him an overhead view of the maze. It's been too long since I read that tale. And it took a while to find the error.

When the first combination of no-help/no-help appeared, my heart sank. When the first combination got solved, big smile and I settled in for some clever cluing. The homophones seemed a bit unfair, but all in all, once the rode-trip got underway things started to move.  While I didn't feel much ARDENCY (???) for this one, it was worth the tsuris and it did get done.

I've been looking forward to the Sunday puzzle(s) returning to their former degree(s) of difficulty.  Mission accomplished!  The past year has renewed my hope and has me looking forward to an honest battle on Sunday.

Took me a while to get it, but enjoyed the puzzle. One thing, though, appears to be an error, at least to me. 

A futon is a mattress. It does not have slats. A folding frame that can turn from a bed to a couch has slats. But that‚Äôs a frame, not a futon. 

Am I the only one that saw this as incorrect?
I generally dislike gimmick puzzles, especially on Sunday. This one was a lot of work (and not much fun).

Took a bit to figure out the trick, but no "Aha!" moment or sense of satisfaction upon doing so - just "Meh." No fun in this puzzle whatsoever. Feels like it's been awhile since I really enjoyed a clever or amusing Sunday installment ....
I liked the theme. The fill required to support the theme was far too esoteric.

There were some brutal crosses in there:  ALAINA  with KIR.  I also struggled with 5A cross with 8D.  I could have sworn that Ohio State U was the largest school in the country.. 

But it's ARIZONA state?  Could have knocked me over with a feather.

Really hard for me.  I don't judge a puzzles fairness, because it seems to be impossible to define.

Maddeningly one square away from a gold star. I had ARDENCE, which seems to me of similar legitimacy to the actual answer. I just figured NOSILE must be some new-to-me word along the lines of puerile or sterile. Dagnabbit!

This one gave a good fight. The theme pulled out a lot of line before I was able to reel it in. ESCAPE/SIDESTEP was the one I figured out from the crossers and the others were not too difficult once I got the pattern.

This felt like a good level of difficulty for a Sunday although I'm sure some will disagree in both directions. Thanks team!
I find that any puzzle which has drawings are really tough for me.  For one thing, it takes me forever, generally, to figure our what it's a picture of.

There are monsters under the bed and I need my daddy to tell me everything will be okay. "What a world! What a world!"

The puzzle took a little longer and served as a distraction.
I am sending some positive vibes to all who need to receive them, myself included.

CLEAR AS MUD until you got it. 

Nice enjoyable puzzle. Non themed clues a bit on the tough side. Nothing dramatic. 

One could quibble on the Bluetooth but it would be overly pedantic. 

Thanks.
I solved it, but I didn‚Äôt enjoy it. Some really off clues (how does an ear clip help with Bluetooth?) and just felt like a chore.
Even though I had a tough time with the theme, any puzzle with Isabella ROSSELLINI, Helen MIRREN, ELENA Kagan and ROSIE the Rivetor is okay by me.

Picture rebuses are my favorite rebuses. When I first saw the cane, I knew I was in for a treat. 

I think what I like most about this type of rebus/crossword mashup is the combination of the written and the aural. Each picture represents a sound, which becomes a syllable that completes a word that must fit the squares. Layers and layers of puzzle, so fun!

More, please.

I still haven't finished the puzzle.

Homophones are the bane of a non-native-speaker crossword solver like me. I can pronounce English just fine, most of the time, but getting homophones does not come easily to me (maybe because Polish has so much less of them than English I'm simply not accustomed to dealing with them). So I sort of get the theme but I can't figure out all of the entries. It's not a nice feeling.

Also, the puzzle is overflowing with proper nouns and trivia, making the fill very frustrating for me. Seeing how much I'd have to look up, I just gave up and started revealing answers. So far during today's solve I've done that two dozen times, if not more.

This may well be a great puzzle for its intended audience, but personally I am not enjoying it. I'm contemplating simply revealing the whole thing.
There's an Arts section in the NYT.  Perhaps picture puzzles should go there.

Meh. Again, a puzzle that's too clever by half. And some of the clues are very poor. An earclip does not help with Bluetooth (it may help with a headset), and a slat is not part of a futon (though it might be part of a futon frame). Not enjoyable.

The note says you can't see the pictures if the app isn't updated.  Well, guess what?  That includes the NYT app where the pictures are missing.  Doesn't work "online"either as promised.  I love gimmicks but they really need to work on your own [bad word] platforms!! No puzzle for me today.  Thanks.

Strands Thread. Save all spoilers for after the View All Replies button. Not really enjoyable for me. The inconsistency of the rebus pictures being the full word in some entries (cane, cape) versus not in other entries (py, mit) added a layer that didn't contribute anything but confusion.
Also, ASU isn't the largest campus by enrollment, according to the Dept of Ed (which actually has the numbers). How is enrollment defined this clue, anyway? Too much of a stretch, like some other clues in this puzzle.
You know how sometimes putting it down then returning is the answer? This one fell on the fifth try!  Sweet!

Holy moly, this must have been tough to construct.  Putting the clue and the answer in the grid, having them cross and managing to have the circled letter spell out REBUSES?  Yikes!  Wonderful job, Rich.

This was one of my slower Sunday solves, but I enjoyed every minute.  I always enjoy a novel trick, and this one was very well done.
Great puzzle, really enjoyed this.
CLEAR AS MUD just doesn‚Äôt feel like an apt definition for the word ARCANE, although I can‚Äôt necessarily say it‚Äôs completely wrong

Tough one for me and did have to cheat a bit to get through it, and... must admit that I still feel like I'm not entirely grasping the trick with at least a couple of the theme answers. I remain appropriately puzzled. That's all on me. And... and appropriate puzzle find today. Don't recall ever seeing another one quite like this. A Sunday from March 18, 199 by David J. Pohl and John M. Samson with the title "Expansion teams." Will confess that I'm not entirely grasping the trick in this one either. Some clue/answer examples: "New York debating team :" BROOKLYNACCENTS "Lebanese pit team :" TYREPATCHERS "Middle Eastern ecdysiast team :" GAZASTRIPPERS "Leg-pulling Welsh team :" CARDIFFGIANTS "Scottish phys. ed. team noted for coolness :" AYRCONDITIONERS "Clumsy Asian skiing team :" SINGAPORESLINGS And there were a couple of others. I remain puzzled. Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/PS?date=3/18/1979&g=59&d=A I'm done. ...

A capital-P Puzzle for me, Stymie City, where I had to shift my brain into a gear that included patience, faith, and a lot of sweat.

I like that gear.  I like this kind of work, where I have to up my game ‚Äì if it‚Äôs fair.  And, for me, it turned out to be.  Despite the hitches that befell me ‚Äì a host of no-knows, ultra-thorny clues, and a tough-to-unravel theme that took up a lot of squares ‚Äì realizations kept popping out, with an ‚ÄúOho!‚Äù here, an ‚ÄúOh yeah!‚Äù there, and, from time to time, a ‚ÄúBingo!‚Äù.

In the end, very satisfying.

This is Rich‚Äôs ninth Times puzzle, with eight of them being themed.  I bring this up because I have loved every one of his themes, pulsing with originality.  Today‚Äôs is his most complicated, where clues and answers intersect in the grid, where pictures are involved, and where the circled letters spell something (Hi,@Nancy J!).  And where the horizontal elements of the theme pairs are symmetrical!

Wow!

Very happy to see you again, Rich, after you‚Äôve been away for three years.  I eagerly await your next, and thank you for a very worthwhile outing!

american acronyms are the absolute bane of my existence as a canadian. kinda mad about 33A, 10D, 11D, and 30D lol, and idk about 22A. NW corner was rough. 

the themed clues were... something. i enjoyed the play on words but not sure how i feel about the circular hints here. it felt like a bit of a slog without any satisfaction for completing it. a fine puzzle, but maybe my standards are too high for sundays.

On paper, this one should have been a delight for me. Real rebuses!
Got the trick after I had a lot of crosses to convince me that BACKSTAB was crossing BETRAY. But that "lot of crosses" was the problem. With seven mutually independent crossing pairs of solutions, I was more dependent on crosses than usual. But I'm already very dependent on crosses as a non-American solver.
So then a bunch of unknown proper nouns and abbreviations; and then some cluing that I found impenetrable. SLAT as part of a futon? TAKE as the [Share from an illicit endeavor]? CLEAR AS MUD clued by ARCANE? And the clue for LAD, ["Wee" fellow] appeared to have been written by Sir Walter Scott.

So at that point I heaved a sigh, killed it with the "Reveal Puzzle" option and went off to do a Sunday puzzle from the archives instead.

Very clever construction, and I'm full of admiration for that, but the result was simply wearisome for me.
Loved the theme, but just never got on the same wavelength with the constructor for the solve.

I admit, I did droop a little a few times, as my enthusiasm for all the tiny bits of arcanity wasn‚Äôt always being rewarded with unmuddy crosses.

But sure, it was a puzzly puzzle, nothing obvious or straightforward about the theme entries, so exactly what we signed up for. The more I think about it, a welcome bit of gristle on a Sunday, which typically is my least favourite day for the XW.

I like crosswords. 

I like Pictionary.

Please pass the dairy.

Yesterday, I spent
*hours* constructing.

Which (CC style) means

Pen and notepad, scratching out theme ideas‚Ä¶
working on one for hours 
and then fighting the urge
to rip it into shreds‚Ä¶

Finally feeling sure enough about one to-

move to my computer, and
*attempt* to assemble a grid that will
be the vessel to carry the theme 
in a way that‚Äôs actually fun to solve.

It ain‚Äôt easy (for me).

So, noting the theme this morning, 
and the three (four?)-pronged aspect of it 
makes my head spin.

It‚Äôs beautiful and complicated
and clever and so very, very impressive.

Mr Proulx, you‚Äôre either working
with a mega-brain,
or you‚Äôre using witchcraft or magic beans
or something.

Either way, fantastic, brilliant construction.

Finished the puzzle, taking almost 5 minutes longer than my average (according to the stats when the jingle played).  I didn‚Äôt love or hate it .. just meh.  A couple of the pictured clues didn‚Äôt make sense.  It felt like a slog towards the end.  But it‚Äôs done.
8D isn't correct. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_public_university_campuses_by_enrollment
As a speaker of British English, I was totally convinced that 101D was oMIT.
This puzzle was 22 Across, all the way.
22A sums it up.

So overall I liked this one quite a bit. Thanks to the ‚ÄúSee XX-Down‚Äù formulation, it was a genuine puzzle in the best sense ‚Äî I was really stumped by the theme until it dawned on me with SIDESTEP/ESCAPE and was confirmed by WORKGROUP/UNIT. After that I enjoyed going back and sussing out CLEARASMUD/ARCANE, EATAWAY/ERODE and BACKSTAB/BETRAY. 

Also, for whatever it‚Äôs worth, I solved without lookups as always. 

My only criticism is that getting the theme depended entirely on the crosses, and many of the crosses were quite tricky IMHO. It felt unnecessarily hard ‚Ä¶ perhaps ‚Äúunkind‚Äù is the word I am looking for.

To wit: 

Around 22A/19D you have the egregious EARCLIP. Used as a standalone noun, ‚Äúearclip‚Äù almost always refers to an earring. Its use in electronics is typically as a modifier to describe a type of earbud, e.g., ‚Äúear clip wireless earbuds.‚Äù In the same region you have the dubious ASU (only correct if you include all campuses in the county), the unusual ARDENCY and the fun-but-esoteric INCAS. 

42A/46D: A random podcast host (ALAINA), the questionable SLAT (cf others) and the only-since-2011 NO BRA DAY, and that‚Äôs not counting ELENA and KIR. 

64A/67D: Four names (MEGAN, MIRREN, ARLO, ANA) plus the unusual KNURL. 

Even 98A/101D needed GILDA and ROSSELLINI and 111A/107D involved NERDY, THREAD and MATEYS, all fair but not gimmes. 

Not the end of the world. But as the day wears on I anticipate lots of grumbling ‚Äî and I can understand where that will be coming from.

I am part way through the puzzle as I write this, and I carefully averted my eyes to avoid seeing any spoilers in order to be able to make a comment.

I'm at the point where it's asking me for a "futon component." I'm sitting on a futon that I've owned for about twenty-five years. Over that time I've disassembled the frame twice, down to the individual boards, and reglued it, to deal with the damage done by two growing boys who would throw themselves on it or allow the back to fall when folding it out. I know every tiny piece of this thing.

I have no idea how to answer this clue.

A clever puzzle although a couple of the sketch-clues were so crude it took me a long while to figure out what they depicted. 19D, for example‚Ä¶for awhile I thought it might be a hook of some sort. In 29D, the arrow points to the landscape beside the road, not the road itself, so was it the shoulder of the road? The hills? Landscape? Still, I managed to pick my way through the grid in only two minutes above my Sunday average.

This is not a crossword puzzle. I am sick of the arrogance of some of these constructors. 
I have no clue what half of these pictures mean. These are supposed to have actual clues. 
I do not know why I'm paying for a service that is not being delivered. I didn't sign up for Concentration with Alex Trebek. I'm going to stop the solve attempt and let my 200+ streak end out of protest.

Well, it certainly challenged me.
I thought I understood all the homophones: nit, py, cape, rode, cane, etc. But ‚Äútray‚Äù required an additional ‚Äúe‚Äù. 
‚Äúetray‚Äù? Can someone enlighten me? 
Considerably over my average, btw.

Fun crunchy puzzle!

And I'm looking forward to trotting out the fun fact about INCAS and freeze drying at work (my company is in the food business).
I thought it was brilliant! Thanks for a terrific puzzle.

Too fussy too finicky too much running to and fro.

Got a lot of it and wasn't having any fun so I quit. Might have been better as a Thursday puzzle? I'm outta here - see you tomorrow

One note - BLUETOOTH isn't just for earbuds
Much fun! It took a long time to get the trick - which made it a delightful aha moment. Great puzzle!üß©

This puzzle hearkens back to the very crunchy, Naticky, unforgiving, frankly mean puzzles of the naughts and nineties and before. Given how easy crosswords are these days, this puzzle was a refreshing slap in the face. Puzzles are supposed to be challenging. I feel so sorry for those of you focused on your solve time and streak more than actually, you know, the challenge in front of you.

I'm seeing a certain tension, here today, between those who find [Aid for using Bluetooth] an unsatisfactory clue for EARCLIP, and those who say "It's metonymy", or "It's a clue, not a definition".
I can see both points of view, but lean towards unsatisfactory.
A clearer example for me is EPEE as a [Saber alternative]. It just isn't, except in the very loose sense of "show me a sword". Of course it's *soluble*, because it's four letters having something to do with swords, but it's a solution that is irksome rather than satisfying, for me. Certainly a different experience from the delight of saying "Of course! That's it!" when I unravelled a knotty cryptic clue yesterday. 

Of course, it wouldn't do if we were all the same, as my grandmother used to say (though we would need fewer television channels). Just trying to explain one of the reasons I ended up shrugging and walking away from this one, despite its clever and interesting theme.
SOFT A is a new one to me.  I‚Äôd have said the vowel sounds in father are a short O and a schwa.

Count me among those who found this puzzle delightful.  Very clever use of the rebus.

And how fun that we get to discuss the difference between the "traditional" rebus, in which symbols and images are placed together to represent a word, and "rebus" as it's being used now in the crossword community to mean putting a symbol or more than one letter in a box.

Those complaining about the problems of E+ROAD =ERODE or B+TRAY=BETRAY may not have adequate experience with the traditional rebus.

(Images of Hugh Downs and "Concentration" dance through one's head.)

Anyone remember an old TV game called "Concentration"?  Hugh Downs was the emcee for a long time.

For you youngsters, there was a board divided into squares.  Each square was a prize or a wild card.  Contestants took turns trying to find matching prize squares, and when they did, those squares were removed, and a little bit of an underlying rebus was shown.

Whoever guessed the rebus won all the prizes they had matched.

I was hopeless at that game.  While I could generally remember where the matches were, I never, EVER, solved the rebus, even when I could see the whole thing, nor did I generally see it when it was explained.

So my heart sank a little when I saw rebuses here.

@Oikofuge In the US, at least, a futon is a certain kind of convertible sofa, although it's not what the Japanese meant by the word originally. Rather than the way a conventional sleeper sofa opens, by removing the seat cushions and revealing a frame and thin mattress inside, a futon converts from a sofa to a bed by rotating the back and the seat, and the back cushion and the seat cushion become the sleeping surface. Maybe it's different in the UK, but in common parlance, the futon is the entire piece of furniture. Here's the first example I came across: https://tinyurl.com/2kzyuh2w To be fair, some of the other hits were of the more traditional definition of mattress only, but there were several of the whole-unit type as well on a Google shopping search. And some of the hits for just the mattress called it a "futon mattress", and for some of the hits for just the frame, it was called a "futon frame", implying that together, they make up the "futon". I will conclude by saying that when my family had such an item, we called the whole thing a futon. Hope this helps!

I turned up discussion of (what seemed to me to be) three different vowel sounds under the rubric of "soft a", as well as having an unexpected deep dive into racist terms of abuse.

SOFT A or any vowel is capital b, capital s. Regardless of the site Barry found, which appears to be aimed at an ESL crowd, there is no standard usage for SOFT and hard with vowels.  Long and short, yes, in a context of phonics for small children, who need it simplified, but linguists don't use those terms at all.

Furthermore, if you look at the various sites that attempt to define a SOFT A, you'll find they're all over the place.  And it has nothing to do with a "th" or "r" following it.

SOFT and HARD have standardized usage with the consonants C and G, where those letters each represent two totally different sounds.  But SOFT A is just...something to fit into a crossword.

I use Check Puzzle on occasion, because sometimes after clearing out your errors, the correct answer becomes immediately clear.
